title: Edmonton Oilers goaltender Ben Scrivens put on waivers | Hockey | Sports | Toron
text:
The Edmonton Oilers have made their decision in goal and Ben Scrivens is the odd man out.
The Oilers put Scrivens on waivers Sunday with the purpose of assigning the goaltender to the Bakersfield Condors of the American Hockey League.
NHL teams have 24 hours to claim Scrivens.
The move leaves Cam Talbot and Anders Nilsson as the Oilers two goaltenders heading into the regular-season opener Thursday, on the road, against the St. Louis Blues.
Scrivens, 29, was acquired by the Oilers in January, 2014 from the Los Angeles Kings. The Spruce Grove product played 21 games for Edmonton that season, posting a 9-11-0 record with a 3.01 goals against average and .916 save percentage.
Shortly after his arrival in Edmonton, Scrivens set an NHL record for most saves in a regular-season shutout, turning aside 59 shots in a 3-0 win over the San Jose Sharks.
On the strength of that performance and his subsequent play the rest of that season, the Oilers signed Scrivens to a two-year extension worth $2.3-million per season. Scrivens is currently in the second year of the deal.
Undrafted, Scrivens began his career in the Toronto Maple Leafs organization after graduating from Cornell University. He played 32 games in three seasons with the Leafs before being traded to the Kings.
Last season, Scrivens struggled with consistency, posting a 15-26-11 record with the Oilers with a 3.16 goals against average and .890 save percentage.
Looking to strengthen their goaltending this season, Oilers new general manager Peter Chiarelli acquired Talbot from the New York Rangers and traded for the rights to Nilsson from the Chicago Blackhawks.
Nilsson signed a one-year, $1-million contract with Edmonton and did not give up a goal during regulation in the preseason.
Talbot is expected to start for the Oilers in the regular-season opener against the Blues.
